Patch Set 30:

(1 comment)

In addition to (or instead of) producing into json array, can we provide it as string array and lambda callback so that we can potentially modify it?

```
getCollectionMembersTo(...., std::function<void(const std::vector<std::string> &members)>&& callback);
```
And then use it to implement `getCollectionMembersArray()`.


This could be useful and utilized later to deal with the attached adapters so that the member names may need to be modified?

An example is to make fabric adapter names to be unique - 
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61512

The similar situation may occur for PCIeDevices.
May be in a different commit. Not planning to do here.
There is no requirement, it should be in a different commit.

The current used subtree is "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory" for both cases - `getCollectionMembers()` and `getPCIeDeviceList()`.
I think we can move subtree parameter to the end as an optional.
Also, the usage pattern of arrayName seems the literal string rather than variable.

Then we can define the function like - 

```
getCollectionMembersArray(std::shared_ptr<bmcweb::AsyncResp> asyncResp,
                              const boost::urls::url& collectionPath,
                              std::span<const std::string_view> interfaces,
                              std::string_view arrayName,
                              const char* subtree = "/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory")
```

If `std::string_view` is used, `arrayName + "@odata.count"` may need to be `std::string(arrayName)+"@odata.count"`

I am not sure why need optional subtree?
In the code, arrayName is already of type std::string, so there is no issue with concatenating it with "@odata.count". I did not understand the comment.

It is not about the functional issue, but it may be better to put the potentially optional argument to the end - esp if `getCollectionMembersArray()` may be used elsewhere.

In that case, `subtree` may not be explicitly specified just like `getCollectionMembers()`.

Then, it is better to put `subtree` argument at the end of the argument list so that those places do not need to pass the default `subtree` value (`"/xyz/openbmc_project/inventory"`).

(It is the same way of defining `getCollectionMembers()`).
Done
And what else?  The validator will happily pass if a collection is empty or incorrect.  Also missing 404 tests.
Done
Your tests showed errors.
I forced the test to to fail in getSubTreePaths, which is giving internal error.  This is causing confusing, removing the test.
Please test the code on master.  Don't add additional code
string_view in new code please.
Changed to string&, underlying call uses const std::string&.
what is an "array name"?  I think you mean "key name", which generally we would just pass in a json_pointer object, but maybe we can't in that case?
Updated the function name and description.
yes, We can pass the json_pointer. I will change the code.

I am unable to use a JSON pointer object to update "@odata.count," and it's not functioning as expected. We have to update "@odata.count" after the function call, which doesn't seem correct.
Updated the function name and description.
Please don't make default parameters like this.  Roll the parameter out to all the users if it's now needed.

Done
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/66802
This lambda doesn't follow the coding standard.  I'm not going to accept anything new into it until it's refactored to make it reviewable.

There is already another commit in progress that is handling the refactoring, and it is dependent on the mapper change being merged. Should I create a separate commit to push the refactoring changes so that we can proceed with these changes?

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/58628

Done
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/66802
Same here.
Done

nit:


```
curl -k https://$bmc/redfish/v1/Systems/system
{
```
Done
what is this internal error from?

If getSubTreePaths fails then we will this error

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/64087/19/redfish-core/include/utils/collection.hpp#38

Can you make that clear in the commit msg?

I assume we allow an empty collection like you have above so why did it fail here?

curl -k https://$bmc/redfish/v1/Systems/system/PCIeDevices
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system/PCIeDevices",
  "@odata.type": "#PCIeDeviceCollection.PCIeDeviceCollection",
  "Description": "Collection of PCIe Devices",
  "Members": [],
  "Members@odata.count": 0,
  "Name": "PCIe Device Collection"
}

The empty collection is a result of initializing the Members array before calling getPCIeDeviceList. This initialization might be necessary for systems without PCIeDevices, as otherwise, the Redfish Validator fails.
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/pcie.hpp#L134

After the refactor, we may no longer need this initialization. getCollectionMembers is expected to handle the initialization of the Members array if there are no PCIeDevices. I will make these changes and then run the Redfish Validator to confirm the behavior."
Removed the initialization of  Members array before calling getPCIeDeviceList. Ran the Redfish Validator.
You have internal errors in your response.  Clearly this is a bug in your code
I forced the test to to fail in getSubTreePaths, which is giving internal error. This is causing confusing, removing the test.
Do you have any rules for custom key name?
There are no specific rules for custom key names. The key name should match whatever the Redfish schema specifies, If it doesn't match then the Redfish validator fails.
?  This doesn't match our naming convention.
Fixed.

nit, lets call this jsonKeyName just to be clear what it is.

Also, consider using the json_pointer class to make it type safe.
Done

It looks like keyName or jsonKeyName seems chosen from the json code point of view.
But isn't this semantically used as the name of collection - e.g. /Members or /PCIeDevices from subTreePaths?
If so, perhaps, 'collectionName' may be better?

Considering that "Members" is the name of the key name that this is now making configurable, maybe this one needs to be called "getCollectionToKey" to be more clear and differentiated from getCollectionMembers?
Changed the name to getCollectionToKey, hope it makes more sense.
Done
I think calling this something like collectionName makes more sense.
Changed to jsonKeyName
Please construct this on its own line and put into a variable name.
Done
This isn't needed because handleCollectionMembers has Members / @odata.count when there isn't any members. Ack.
Thanks for the review. I was on vacation, took a while to resolve the issues.
I will try this. Thx
Done

This seems excessive operations - i.e. json_pointer -> std::string -> substr & string + concat.
Isn't it caused because jsonKeyName starts with "/" (e.g. json_pointer("/Members"))? 
It also requires jsonKeyName must start with "/" at the caller.  It seems potentially error-prone.

I think It may be simpler to use  jsonKeyName (or collectionName etc) without "/" - perhaps a simple string or string_view, and then construct json_pointer inside handleCollectionMembers()?
I'm not really sure why we need to strip the beginning / here?

If the leading "/" is not removed, the output will be incorrect:

"Members": [],
"/Members@odata.count": 0,

If the caller provides `jsonKeyName` without a leading "/", it results in a core dump. Let me see if I can add "/" in handleCollectionMembers.
Adding "/" in handleCollectionMembers is not working; it still causes core dumps. I attempted to address it by using jsonCountKeyName.pop_back, as recommended by Ed.

I think it seems much simpler if we use 'string' at the place of 'keyname' (or collection name) instead of json_pointer. (I also think this keyname is not the json entry itself but specifier of json elements).

So, I would vote to use `string` for this keyname.

> So, I would vote to use string for this keyname.

String doesn't enforce any type safety.  I'd rather we have code that's more complex, with enforced type safety.  We'd done similar themes with things like dbus paths in the past.

The biggest thing is that nlohmann::json operator[](std::string) throws.  The json_pointer version doesn't.
Done
Patchset 26 looks like its' something that can merge.  If we get that to the top of the stack, we should be good to go.
I have pushed patchset 26 on top, Please review. Thx

This is a typo, and it needs to be `@odata.count`.

(I tried to push a new commit for this, but somehow my gerrit push is rejected)
This should not have been static.  Its been fixed.
